member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Certificate.DeleteAsync(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Deletes the certificate from the Batch account.
member.param: A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: A that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: The delete operation requests that the certificate be deleted. The request puts the certificate in the state. The Batch service will perform the actual certificate deletion without any further client action.
You cannot delete a certificate if a resource (pool or compute node) is using it. Before you can delete a certificate, you must therefore make sure that:

item.description: The certificate is not associated with any pools.
The certificate is not installed on any compute nodes. (Even if you remove a certificate from a pool, it is not removed from existing compute nodes in that pool until they restart.)

remarks.para: If you try to delete a certificate that is in use, the deletion fails. The certificate state changes to . You can use to set the status back to Active if you decide that you want to continue using the certificate.
The delete operation runs asynchronously.

remarks.para: Updates an existing on the Batch service by replacing its properties with the properties of this which have been changed. Unchanged properties are ignored. All changes since the last time this entity was retrieved from the Batch service (either via , , or ) are applied. Properties which are explicitly set to null will cause an exception because the Batch service does not support partial updates which set a property to null. If you need to set a property to null, use .
This operation runs asynchronously.

member.summary: Adds a single task to this . To add multiple tasks, use JobOperations.AddTaskAsync.
member.param: The to add.
An optional collection to customize and receive information about the file staging process (see ). For more information see .
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: A that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: Each call to this method incurs a request to the Batch service. Therefore, using this method to add multiple tasks is less efficient than using a bulk add method, and can incur HTTP connection restrictions. If you are performing many of these operations in parallel and are seeing client side timeouts (a ), please see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.servicepointmanager.defaultconnectionlimit%28v=vs.110%29.aspx or use .
The add task operation runs asynchronously.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudJob.AddTask(Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior})
member.summary: Adds a single task to this . To add multiple tasks, use JobOperations.AddTaskAsync.
member.param: The to add.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
member.returns: A collection of information about the file staging process (see ). For more information see .

remarks.para: Each call to this method incurs a request to the Batch service. Therefore, using this method to add multiple tasks is less efficient than using a bulk add method, and can incur HTTP connection restrictions. If you are performing many of these operations in parallel and are seeing client side timeouts (a ), please see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.servicepointmanager.defaultconnectionlimit%28v=vs.110%29.aspx or use .
This is a blocking operation. For a non-blocking equivalent, see .

member.summary: Adds tasks to a job.
member.param: The s to add.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .

Controls the number of simultaneous parallel AddTaskCollection requests issued to the Batch service. Each AddTaskCollection request contains at most tasks in it. Also controls the cancellation token for the operation. If omitted, the default is used (see .)

An optional collection to receive information about the file staging process (see ). An entry is added to the for each set of tasks grouped for submission to the Batch service. Unlike single-task adds, you cannot use this parameter to customize the file staging process. For more information about the format of each entry, see .
The amount of time after which the operation times out.
member.returns: A object that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: The add task operation runs asynchronously.

This method is not atomic; that is, it is possible for the method to start adding tasks and then fail. The collection of tasks to add is broken down into chunks of size at most , and an AddTaskCollection request is issued for each chunk. Requests may be issued in parallel according to the .

Issuing a large number of simultaneous requests to the Batch service can incur HTTP connection restrictions. If you are performing many of these operations in parallel (or have specified a large MaxDegreeOfParallelism in the parallelOptions) and are seeing client side timeouts (a ), please see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.servicepointmanager.defaultconnectionlimit%28v=vs.110%29.aspx .

The progress of the operation in the face of errors is determined by behavior. You do not normally need to specify this behavior, as the Batch client uses a default which works in normal circumstances. If you do want to customize this behavior, specify an AddTaskCollectionResultHandler in the or collections.

member.exception: Thrown if one or more requests to the Batch service fail.

member.summary: Resizes this pool.
member.param: The desired number of dedicated compute nodes in the pool. At least one of and is required.
The desired number of low-priority compute nodes in the pool. At least one of and is required.

The timeout for allocation of compute nodes to the pool or removal of compute nodes from the pool. If the pool has not reached the target size after this time, the resize is stopped. The default is 15 minutes.
Specifies how to handle tasks already running, and when the nodes running them may be removed from the pool, if the pool size is decreasing. The default is .
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: A that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: The resize operation requests that the pool be resized. The request puts the pool in the allocation state. The Batch service will perform the actual resize without any further client action, and set the allocation state to once complete.

You can only resize a pool when its is . You cannot resize pools which are configured for automatic scaling (that is, the property of the pool is true). If you decrease the pool size, the Batch service chooses which nodes to remove. To remove specific nodes, call .
The resize operation runs asynchronously.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask
member.summary: An Azure Batch task. A task is a piece of work that is associated with a job and runs on a compute node.
An Azure Batch task. A task is a piece of work that is associated with a job and runs on a compute node.
member.remarks: Batch will retry tasks when a recovery operation is triggered on a compute node. Examples of recovery operations include (but are not limited to) when an unhealthy compute node is rebooted or a compute node disappeared due to host failure. Retries due to recovery operations are independent of and are not counted against the . Even if the is 0, an internal retry due to a recovery operation may occur. Because of this, all tasks should be idempotent. This means tasks need to tolerate being interrupted and restarted without causing any corruption or duplicate data. The best practice for long running tasks is to use some form of checkpointing. The maximum lifetime of a task from addition to completion is 180 days. If a task has not completed within 180 days of being added it will be terminated by the Batch service and left in whatever state it was in at that time.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.CustomBehaviors
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of behaviors that modify or customize requests to the Batch service made via this .

remarks.para: These behaviors are inherited by child objects.
Modifications are applied in the order of the collection. The last write wins.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.AffinityInformation
member.summary: Gets or sets a locality hint that can be used by the Batch service to select a node on which to start the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.ApplicationPackageReferences
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of application packages that the Batch service will deploy to the compute node before running the command line.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.AuthenticationTokenSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets the settings for an authentication token that the task can use to perform Batch service operations.
member.remarks: If this property is set, the Batch service provides the task with an authentication token which can be used to authenticate Batch service operations without requiring an account access key. The token is provided via the AZ_BATCH_AUTHENTICATION_TOKEN environment variable. The operations that the task can carry out using the token depend on the settings. For example, a task can request job permissions in order to add other tasks to the job, or check the status of the job or of other tasks.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.CommandLine
member.summary: Gets or sets the command line of the task.
member.remarks: The command line does not run under a shell, and therefore cannot take advantage of shell features such as environment variable expansion. If you want to take advantage of such features, you should invoke the shell in the command line, for example using \"cmd /c MyCommand\" in Windows or \"/bin/sh -c MyCommand\" in Linux. If the command line refers to file paths, it should use a relative path (relative to the task working directory), or use the Batch provided environment variables (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/batch/batch-compute-node-environment-variables).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.ComputeNodeInformation
member.summary: Gets information about the compute node on which the task ran.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.Constraints
member.summary: Gets or sets the execution constraints that apply to this task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.ContainerSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets the settings for the container under which the task runs.
member.remarks: If the pool that will run this task has set, this must be set as well. If the pool that will run this task doesn't have set, this must not be set. When this is specified, all directories recursively below the AZ_BATCH_NODE_ROOT_DIR (the root of Azure Batch directories on the node) are mapped into the container, all task environment variables are mapped into the container, and the task command line is executed in the container. Files produced in the container outside of AZ_BATCH_NODE_ROOT_DIR might not be reflected to the host disk, meaning that Batch file APIs will not be able to access them.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.CreationTime
member.summary: Gets the creation time of the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.DependsOn
member.summary: Gets or sets any other tasks that this depends on. The task will not be scheduled until all depended-on tasks have completed successfully.
member.remarks: The job must set to true in order to use task dependencies. If UsesTaskDependencies is false (the default), adding a task with dependencies will fail with an error.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.DisplayName

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.OutputFiles

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.PreviousState
member.summary: Gets the previous state of the task.
member.remarks: If the task is in its initial state, the PreviousState property is not defined.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.PreviousStateTransitionTime
member.summary: Gets the time at which the task entered its previous state.
member.remarks: If the task is in its initial state, the PreviousStateTransitionTime property is not defined.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.ResourceFiles
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of files that the Batch service will download to the compute node before running the command line.
member.remarks: There is a maximum size for the list of resource files. When the max size is exceeded, the request will fail and the response error code will be RequestEntityTooLarge. If this occurs, the collection of resource files must be reduced in size. This can be achieved using .zip files, Application Packages, or Docker Containers.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.State
member.summary: Gets the current state of the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.StateTransitionTime
member.summary: Gets the time at which the task entered its current state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.Statistics
member.summary: Gets resource usage statistics for the task.
member.remarks: This property is populated only if the was retrieved with an including the 'stats' attribute; otherwise it is null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.Url
member.summary: Gets the URL of the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask.UserIdentity
member.summary: Gets or sets the user identity under which the task runs.
member.remarks: If omitted, the task runs as a non-administrative user unique to the task.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeDeallocationOption
member.summary: Specifies how to handle tasks already running, and when the nodes running them may be removed from the pool, if the pool size is decreasing.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeDeallocationOption.Requeue
member.summary: Terminate running tasks and requeue them. The tasks will run again when the job is enabled. Remove nodes as soon as tasks have been terminated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeDeallocationOption.Terminate
member.summary: Terminate running tasks. The tasks will not run again. Remove nodes as soon as tasks have been terminated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeDeallocationOption.TaskCompletion
member.summary: Allow currently running tasks to complete. Schedule no new tasks while waiting. Remove nodes when all tasks have completed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeDeallocationOption.RetainedData
member.summary: Allow currently running tasks to complete, then wait for all task data retention periods to expire. Schedule no new tasks while waiting. Remove nodes when all task retention periods have expired.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeFillType
member.summary: Specifies how tasks should be distributed across compute nodes.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeFillType.Spread
member.summary: Tasks should be assigned evenly across all nodes in the pool.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeFillType.Pack
member.summary: As many tasks as possible (maxTasksPerNode) should be assigned to each node in the pool before any tasks are assigned to the next node in the pool.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeRebootOption
member.summary: Specifies when to reboot a compute node and what to do with currently running tasks.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeRebootOption.Requeue
member.summary: Terminate running tasks and requeue them. The tasks will run again when the job is enabled. Restart the compute node as soon as tasks have been terminated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeRebootOption.Terminate
member.summary: Terminate running tasks. The tasks will not run again. Restart the compute node as soon as tasks have been terminated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeRebootOption.TaskCompletion
member.summary: Allow currently running tasks to complete. Schedule no new tasks while waiting. Restart the compute node when all tasks have completed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeRebootOption.RetainedData
member.summary: Allow currently running tasks to complete, then wait for all task data retention periods to expire. Schedule no new tasks while waiting. Restart the compute node when all task retention periods have expired.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeReimageOption
member.summary: Specifies when to reimage the compute node and what to do with currently running tasks.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeReimageOption.Requeue
member.summary: Terminate running tasks and requeue them. The tasks will run again when the job is enabled. Reimage the compute node as soon as tasks have been terminated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeReimageOption.Terminate
member.summary: Terminate running tasks. The tasks will not run again. Reimage the compute node as soon as tasks have been terminated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeReimageOption.TaskCompletion
member.summary: Allow currently running tasks to complete. Schedule no new tasks while waiting. Reimage the compute node when all tasks have completed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeReimageOption.RetainedData
member.summary: Allow currently running tasks to complete, then wait for all task data retention periods to expire. Schedule no new tasks while waiting. Reimage the compute node when all task retention periods have expired.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState
member.summary: The state of a compute node.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Idle
member.summary: The compute node is not currently running a task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Rebooting
member.summary: The compute node is rebooting.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Reimaging
member.summary: The compute node is being reimaged.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Running
member.summary: The compute node is running one or more tasks (other than the start task).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Unusable
member.summary: The compute node cannot be used for task execution due to errors.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Creating
member.summary: The Batch service has obtained the underlying virtual machine from Azure Compute, but it has not yet started to join a pool.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Starting
member.summary: The Batch service is starting on the underlying virtual machine.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.WaitingForStartTask
member.summary: The start task has started running on the compute node, but waitForSuccess is set and the start task has not yet completed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.StartTaskFailed
member.summary: The start task has failed on the compute node (and exhausted all retries), and waitForSuccess is set. The node is not usable for running tasks.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Unknown
member.summary: The Batch service has lost contact with the compute node, and does not know its true state.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.LeavingPool
member.summary: The compute node is leaving the pool, either because the user explicitly removed it or because the pool is resizing or autoscaling down.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Offline
member.summary: The Batch service will not schedule any new tasks on the compute node.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.ComputeNodeState.Preempted
member.summary: The compute node has been preempted.

remarks.para: The Batch service will not schedule any new tasks on the compute node and any tasks which were running at the time of preemption were requeued. The Batch service will attempt to recover nodes which are in this state. After recovery, all data that was on the node at the time of the preemption is gone.
You are not charged for compute nodes that have been preempted.
This can only occurr on nodes where is false.

member.summary: The task is currently running (including retrying).

member.summary: The state of a Job Release task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobReleaseTaskState.Running
member.summary: The task is currently running.

member.summary: The task has exited, or the Batch service was unable to start the task due to scheduling errors.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobScheduleState
member.summary: The state of a job schedule.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobScheduleState.Active
member.summary: The job schedule is active and will create jobs as per its schedule.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobScheduleState.Completed
member.summary: The schedule has terminated, either by reaching its end time or by the user terminating it explicitly.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobScheduleState.Disabled
member.summary: The user has disabled the schedule. The scheduler will not initiate any new jobs will on this schedule, but any existing active job will continue to run.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobScheduleState.Terminating
member.summary: The schedule has no more work to do, or has been explicitly terminated by the user, but the termination operation is still in progress. The scheduler will not initiate any new jobs for this schedule, nor is any existing job active.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobScheduleState.Deleting
member.summary: The user has requested that the schedule be deleted, but the delete operation is still in progress. The scheduler will not initiate any new jobs for this schedule, but any existing active job will continue to run. The schedule will be deleted when the existing job completes.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobState
member.summary: The state of job

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobState.Active
member.summary: The job is available to have tasks scheduled.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobState.Disabling
member.summary: A user has requested that the job be disabled, but the disable operation is still in progress (for example, waiting for tasks to terminate).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobState.Disabled
member.summary: A user has disabled the job. No tasks are running, and no new tasks will be scheduled.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobState.Enabling
member.summary: A user has requested that the job be enabled, but the enable operation is still in progress.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobState.Terminating
member.summary: The job is about to complete, either because a Job Manager task has completed or because the user has terminated the job, but the terminate operation is still in progress (for example, because Job Release tasks are running).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobState.Completed
member.summary: All tasks have terminated, and the system will not accept any more tasks or any further changes to the job.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.JobState.Deleting
member.summary: A user has requested that the job be deleted, but the delete operation is still in progress (for example, because the system is still terminating running tasks).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.SubtaskState

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.SubtaskState.Preparing
member.summary: The subtask has been assigned to a compute node, but is waiting for a required Job Preparation task to complete on the node.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.SubtaskState.Running
member.summary: The subtask is running on a compute node.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.SubtaskState.Completed
member.summary: The subtask is no longer eligible to run, usually because the it has finished successfully, or the subtask has finished unsuccessfully and has exhausted its retry limit. A subtask is also marked as completed if an error occurred launching the subtask, or when the subtask has been terminated.

member.summary: The task ran successfully.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.TaskExecutionResult.Failure
member.summary: There was an error during processing of the task. The failure may have occurred before the task process was launched, while the task process was executing, or after the task process exited.

member.summary: The task has been assigned to a compute node, but is waiting for a required Job Preparation task to complete on the node.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.TaskState.Completed
member.summary: The task is no longer eligible to run, usually because the task has finished successfully, or the task has finished unsuccessfully and has exhausted its retry limit. A task is also marked as completed if an error occurred launching the task, or when the task has been terminated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.UploadComputeNodeBatchServiceLogsAsync(System.String,System.DateTime,System.Nullable{System.DateTime},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Upload Azure Batch service log files from the compute node.
member.param: The URL of the container within Azure Blob Storage to which to upload the Batch Service log file(s). The URL must include a Shared Access Signature (SAS) granting write permissions to the container.

The start of the time range from which to upload Batch Service log file(s). Any log file containing a log message in the time range will be uploaded. This means that the operation might retrieve more logs than have been requested since the entire log file is always uploaded.

The end of the time range from which to upload Batch Service log file(s). Any log file containing a log message in the time range will be uploaded. This means that the operation might retrieve more logs than have been requested since the entire log file is always uploaded. If this is omitted, the default is the current time.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: A that represents the asynchronous operation.
member.remarks: This is for gathering Azure Batch service log files in an automated fashion from nodes if you are experiencing an error and wish to escalate to Azure support. The Azure Batch service log files should be shared with Azure support to aid in debugging issues with the Batch service.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.UploadComputeNodeBatchServiceLogs(System.String,System.DateTime,System.Nullable{System.DateTime},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior})

member.param: The URL of the container within Azure Blob Storage to which to upload the Batch Service log file(s). The URL must include a Shared Access Signature (SAS) granting write permissions to the container.

The start of the time range from which to upload Batch Service log file(s). Any log file containing a log message in the time range will be uploaded. This means that the operation might retrieve more logs than have been requested since the entire log file is always uploaded.

The end of the time range from which to upload Batch Service log file(s). Any log file containing a log message in the time range will be uploaded. This means that the operation might retrieve more logs than have been requested since the entire log file is always uploaded. If this is omitted, the default is the current time.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
member.remarks: This is for gathering Azure Batch service log files in an automated fashion from nodes if you are experiencing an error and wish to escalate to Azure support. The Azure Batch service log files should be shared with Azure support to aid in debugging issues with the Batch service.
member.returns: The result of uploading the batch service logs.

member.summary: Gets the execution information for the most recent tasks that ran on this compute node. Note that this element is only returned if at least one task was run on this compute node since the time it was assigned to its current pool.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.RunningTasksCount
member.summary: Gets the total number of currently running tasks on the compute node. This includes Job Preparation, Job Release, and Job Manager tasks, but not the pool start task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.SchedulingState
member.summary: Gets whether the node is available for task scheduling.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.StartTask
member.summary: Gets the start task associated with all compute nodes in this pool.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.StartTaskInformation
member.summary: Gets the detailed runtime information of the start task, including current state, error details, exit code, start time, end time, etc.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.State
member.summary: Gets the current state of the compute node.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.StateTransitionTime
member.summary: Gets the time at which the compute node entered the current state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.TotalTasksRun
member.summary: Gets the number of tasks that have been run on this compute node from the time it was allocated to this pool. This includes Job Preparation, Job Release, and Job Manager tasks, but not the pool start task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.TotalTasksSucceeded
member.summary: Gets the total number of tasks which completed successfully (with exitCode 0) on the compute node. This includes Job Preparation, Job Release, and Job Manager tasks, but not the pool start task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.Url
member.summary: Gets the URL of compute node.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNode.VirtualMachineSize
member.summary: Gets the size of the virtual machine hosting the compute node.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNodeUser.CustomBehaviors
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of behaviors that modify or customize requests to the Batch service made via this .

remarks.para: These behaviors are inherited by child objects.
Modifications are applied in the order of the collection. The last write wins.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNodeUser.ExpiryTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the expiry time.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNodeUser.IsAdmin
member.summary: Gets or sets the administrative privilege level of the user account. The value of this property is ignored when UpdateUser is specified for the commit operation.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNodeUser.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name. If AddUser is specified for the commit operation, the value of this property is the name of the local Windows account created. If UpdateUser is specified for the commit operation, the value of this property selects the local Windows account to modify. Changing this property does not rename the local Windows account on the compute node.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNodeUser.Password
member.summary: Gets or sets the password.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ComputeNodeUser.SshPublicKey
member.summary: Gets or sets the SSH public key that can be used for remote login to the compute node.

remarks.para: The public key should be compatible with Open SSH encoding and should be base 64 encoded. This property can be specified only for Linux nodes. The Batch service will return an error if this property is set for pools created with or with Windows compute nodes.

member.summary: Creates buckets for the FileStagingProviders.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.FileStaging.IFileStagingProvider
member.summary: Provides basic file staging features.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.FileStaging.IFileStagingProvider.StageFilesAsync(System.Collections.Generic.List{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.FileStaging.IFileStagingProvider},Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IFileStagingArtifact)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous operation to stage all of the files in the given collection. When file staging begins, all instances of IFileStagingProvider are bucketized by their implementation type. This produces one collection of instances per implementation. Each implmentation of IFileStagingProvider has a StageFilesAsync() method. That method is called once with the collection produced by the bucketization step oulined above.
member.param: Collection of all file staging objects to be staged. All instances must have the same implementation type.
IFileStagingProvider specific staging artifacts including error/progress.
member.returns: A object that represents the asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.FileStaging.IFileStagingProvider.CreateStagingArtifact
member.summary: Returns an instance of IFileStagingArtifact with whatever values the implementation requires. This will be called during file staging whenever a staging artifact has not been otherwise provided.
member.returns: An instance of IFileStagingArtifact with whatever values the implementation requires.

member.summary: Performs client-side validation on the current object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.FileStaging.IFileStagingProvider.StagedFiles
member.summary: The collection of ResourceFile objects that are the result of file staging. Must be set by the IFileStagingProvider.StageFilesAsync() method.

member.summary: Cancels a failed deletion of a Certificate from the specified Account.
member.remarks: If you try to delete a Certificate that is being used by a Pool or Compute Node, the status of the Certificate changes to deleteFailed. If you decide that you want to continue using the Certificate, you can use this operation to set the status of the Certificate back to active. If you intend to delete the Certificate, you do not need to run this operation after the deletion failed. You must make sure that the Certificate is not being used by any resources, and then you can try again to delete the Certificate.
member.param: The algorithm used to derive the thumbprint parameter. This must be sha1.
The thumbprint of the Certificate being deleted.

member.summary: Deletes a Certificate from the specified Account.
member.remarks: You cannot delete a Certificate if a resource (Pool or Compute Node) is using it. Before you can delete a Certificate, you must therefore make sure that the Certificate is not associated with any existing Pools, the Certificate is not installed on any Nodes (even if you remove a Certificate from a Pool, it is not removed from existing Compute Nodes in that Pool until they restart), and no running Tasks depend on the Certificate. If you try to delete a Certificate that is in use, the deletion fails. The Certificate status changes to deleteFailed. You can use Cancel Delete Certificate to set the status back to active if you decide that you want to continue using the Certificate.
member.param: The algorithm used to derive the thumbprint parameter. This must be sha1.
The thumbprint of the Certificate to be deleted.

member.summary: Gets the settings required for remote login to a Compute Node.
member.remarks: Before you can remotely login to a Compute Node using the remote login settings, you must create a user Account on the Compute Node. member.summary: Upload Azure Batch service log files from the specified Compute Node to Azure Blob Storage.

member.summary: Cancels a failed deletion of a Certificate from the specified Account.
member.remarks: If you try to delete a Certificate that is being used by a Pool or Compute Node, the status of the Certificate changes to deleteFailed. If you decide that you want to continue using the Certificate, you can use this operation to set the status of the Certificate back to active. If you intend to delete the Certificate, you do not need to run this operation after the deletion failed. You must make sure that the Certificate is not being used by any resources, and then you can try again to delete the Certificate.
member.param: The algorithm used to derive the thumbprint parameter. This must be sha1.
The thumbprint of the Certificate being deleted.

member.summary: Deletes a Certificate from the specified Account.
member.remarks: You cannot delete a Certificate if a resource (Pool or Compute Node) is using it. Before you can delete a Certificate, you must therefore make sure that the Certificate is not associated with any existing Pools, the Certificate is not installed on any Nodes (even if you remove a Certificate from a Pool, it is not removed from existing Compute Nodes in that Pool until they restart), and no running Tasks depend on the Certificate. If you try to delete a Certificate that is in use, the deletion fails. The Certificate status changes to deleteFailed. You can use Cancel Delete Certificate to set the status back to active if you decide that you want to continue using the Certificate.
member.param: The algorithm used to derive the thumbprint parameter. This must be sha1.
The thumbprint of the Certificate to be deleted.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.IJobOperations.DeleteWithHttpMessagesAsync(System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.JobDeleteOptions,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String}},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Deletes a Job.
member.remarks: Deleting a Job also deletes all Tasks that are part of that Job, and all Job statistics. This also overrides the retention period for Task data; that is, if the Job contains Tasks which are still retained on Compute Nodes, the Batch services deletes those Tasks' working directories and all their contents. When a Delete Job request is received, the Batch service sets the Job to the deleting state. All update operations on a Job that is in deleting state will fail with status code 409 (Conflict), with additional information indicating that the Job is being deleted.
member.param: The ID of the Job to delete.
Additional parameters for the operation
The headers that will be added to request.
The cancellation token.

Thrown when a required parameter is null

member.summary: Disables the specified Job, preventing new Tasks from running.
member.remarks: The Batch Service immediately moves the Job to the disabling state. Batch then uses the disableTasks parameter to determine what to do with the currently running Tasks of the Job. The Job remains in the disabling state until the disable operation is completed and all Tasks have been dealt with according to the disableTasks option; the Job then moves to the disabled state. No new Tasks are started under the Job until it moves back to active state. If you try to disable a Job that is in any state other than active, disabling, or disabled, the request fails with status code 409.
member.param: The ID of the Job to disable.
What to do with active Tasks associated with the Job. Possible values include: 'requeue', 'terminate', 'wait'

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.IJobOperations.EnableWithHttpMessagesAsync(System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.JobEnableOptions,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String}},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Enables the specified Job, allowing new Tasks to run.
member.remarks: When you call this API, the Batch service sets a disabled Job to the enabling state. After the this operation is completed, the Job moves to the active state, and scheduling of new Tasks under the Job resumes. The Batch service does not allow a Task to remain in the active state for more than 180 days. Therefore, if you enable a Job containing active Tasks which were added more than 180 days ago, those Tasks will not run.
member.param: The ID of the Job to enable.
Additional parameters for the operation
The headers that will be added to request.
The cancellation token.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.IJobOperations.TerminateWithHttpMessagesAsync(System.String,System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.JobTerminateOptions,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String}},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Terminates the specified Job, marking it as completed.
member.remarks: When a Terminate Job request is received, the Batch service sets the Job to the terminating state. The Batch service then terminates any running Tasks associated with the Job and runs any required Job release Tasks. Then the Job moves into the completed state. If there are any Tasks in the Job in the active state, they will remain in the active state. Once a Job is terminated, new Tasks cannot be added and any remaining active Tasks will not be scheduled.
member.param: The ID of the Job to terminate.
The text you want to appear as the Job's TerminateReason. The default is 'UserTerminate'.
Additional parameters for the operation
The headers that will be added to request.
The cancellation token.
member.exception: Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code
Thrown when a required parameter is null

member.summary: Adds a Job to the specified Account.
member.remarks: The Batch service supports two ways to control the work done as part of a Job. In the first approach, the user specifies a Job Manager Task. The Batch service launches this Task when it is ready to start the Job. The Job Manager Task controls all other Tasks that run under this Job, by using the Task APIs. In the second approach, the user directly controls the execution of Tasks under an active Job, by using the Task APIs. Also note: when naming Jobs, avoid including sensitive information such as user names or secret project names. This information may appear in telemetry logs accessible to Microsoft Support engineers.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.IPoolOperations.DeleteWithHttpMessagesAsync(System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.PoolDeleteOptions,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String}},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Deletes a Pool from the specified Account.
member.remarks: When you request that a Pool be deleted, the following actions occur: the Pool state is set to deleting; any ongoing resize operation on the Pool are stopped; the Batch service starts resizing the Pool to zero Compute Nodes; any Tasks running on existing Compute Nodes are terminated and requeued (as if a resize Pool operation had been requested with the default requeue option); finally, the Pool is removed from the system. Because running Tasks are requeued, the user can rerun these Tasks by updating their Job to target a different Pool. The Tasks can then run on the new Pool. If you want to override the requeue behavior, then you should call resize Pool explicitly to shrink the Pool to zero size before deleting the Pool. If you call an Update, Patch or Delete API on a Pool in the deleting state, it will fail with HTTP status code 409 with error code PoolBeingDeleted.
member.param: The ID of the Pool to delete.
Additional parameters for the operation
The headers that will be added to request.
The cancellation token.
member.exception: Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code
Thrown when a required parameter is null

member.summary: Enables automatic scaling for a Pool.

If automatic scaling of the Pool is currently disabled, you must specify a valid autoscale formula as part of the request. If automatic scaling of the Pool is already enabled, you may specify a new autoscale formula and/or a new evaluation interval. member.remarks: You can only resize a Pool when its allocation state is steady. If the Pool is already resizing, the request fails with status code 409. When you resize a Pool, the Pool's allocation state changes from steady to resizing. You cannot resize Pools which are configured for automatic scaling. If you try to do this, the Batch service returns an error 409. If you resize a Pool downwards, the Batch service chooses which Compute Nodes to remove. To remove specific Compute Nodes, use the Pool remove Compute Nodes API instead.

member.summary: Stops an ongoing resize operation on the Pool.
member.remarks: This does not restore the Pool to its previous state before the resize operation: it only stops any further changes being made, and the Pool maintains its current state. After stopping, the Pool stabilizes at the number of Compute Nodes it was at when the stop operation was done. During the stop operation, the Pool allocation state changes first to stopping and then to steady. A resize operation need not be an explicit resize Pool request; this API can also be used to halt the initial sizing of the Pool when it is created.
member.param: The ID of the Pool whose resizing you want to stop.

member.summary: Adds a collection of Tasks to the specified Job.
member.remarks: Note that each Task must have a unique ID. The Batch service may not return the results for each Task in the same order the Tasks were submitted in this request. If the server times out or the connection is closed during the request, the request may have been partially or fully processed, or not at all. In such cases, the user should re-issue the request. Note that it is up to the user to correctly handle failures when re-issuing a request. For example, you should use the same Task IDs during a retry so that if the prior operation succeeded, the retry will not create extra Tasks unexpectedly. If the response contains any Tasks which failed to add, a client can retry the request. In a retry, it is most efficient to resubmit only Tasks that failed to add, and to omit Tasks that were successfully added on the first attempt. The maximum lifetime of a Task from addition to completion is 180 days. If a Task has not completed within 180 days of being added it will be terminated by the Batch service and left in whatever state it was in at that time.
member.param: The ID of the Job to which the Task collection is to be added.

The collection of Tasks to add. The maximum count of Tasks is 100. The total serialized size of this collection must be less than 1MB. If it is greater than 1MB (for example if each Task has 100's of resource files or environment variables), the request will fail with code 'RequestBodyTooLarge' and should be retried again with fewer Tasks.

member.summary: Reactivates a Task, allowing it to run again even if its retry count has been exhausted.
member.remarks: Reactivation makes a Task eligible to be retried again up to its maximum retry count. The Task's state is changed to active. As the Task is no longer in the completed state, any previous exit code or failure information is no longer available after reactivation. Each time a Task is reactivated, its retry count is reset to 0. Reactivation will fail for Tasks that are not completed or that previously completed successfully (with an exit code of 0). Additionally, it will fail if the Job has completed (or is terminating or deleting).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.JobOperations.DeleteWithHttpMessagesAsync(System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.JobDeleteOptions,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String}},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Deletes a Job.
member.remarks: Deleting a Job also deletes all Tasks that are part of that Job, and all Job statistics. This also overrides the retention period for Task data; that is, if the Job contains Tasks which are still retained on Compute Nodes, the Batch services deletes those Tasks' working directories and all their contents. When a Delete Job request is received, the Batch service sets the Job to the deleting state. All update operations on a Job that is in deleting state will fail with status code 409 (Conflict), with additional information indicating that the Job is being deleted.

member.summary: Disables the specified Job, preventing new Tasks from running.
member.remarks: The Batch Service immediately moves the Job to the disabling state. Batch then uses the disableTasks parameter to determine what to do with the currently running Tasks of the Job. The Job remains in the disabling state until the disable operation is completed and all Tasks have been dealt with according to the disableTasks option; the Job then moves to the disabled state. No new Tasks are started under the Job until it moves back to active state. If you try to disable a Job that is in any state other than active, disabling, or disabled, the request fails with status code 409.
member.param: The ID of the Job to disable.
What to do with active Tasks associated with the Job. Possible values include: 'requeue', 'terminate', 'wait'

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.JobOperations.EnableWithHttpMessagesAsync(System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.JobEnableOptions,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String}},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Enables the specified Job, allowing new Tasks to run.
member.remarks: When you call this API, the Batch service sets a disabled Job to the enabling state. After the this operation is completed, the Job moves to the active state, and scheduling of new Tasks under the Job resumes. The Batch service does not allow a Task to remain in the active state for more than 180 days. Therefore, if you enable a Job containing active Tasks which were added more than 180 days ago, those Tasks will not run.
member.param: The ID of the Job to enable.
Additional parameters for the operation
Headers that will be added to request.
The cancellation token.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.JobOperations.TerminateWithHttpMessagesAsync(System.String,System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.JobTerminateOptions,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String}},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Terminates the specified Job, marking it as completed.
member.remarks: When a Terminate Job request is received, the Batch service sets the Job to the terminating state. The Batch service then terminates any running Tasks associated with the Job and runs any required Job release Tasks. Then the Job moves into the completed state. If there are any Tasks in the Job in the active state, they will remain in the active state. Once a Job is terminated, new Tasks cannot be added and any remaining active Tasks will not be scheduled.
member.param: The ID of the Job to terminate.
The text you want to appear as the Job's TerminateReason. The default is 'UserTerminate'.
Additional parameters for the operation
Headers that will be added to request.
The cancellation token.

member.summary: Adds a Job to the specified Account.
member.remarks: The Batch service supports two ways to control the work done as part of a Job. In the first approach, the user specifies a Job Manager Task. The Batch service launches this Task when it is ready to start the Job. The Job Manager Task controls all other Tasks that run under this Job, by using the Task APIs. In the second approach, the user directly controls the execution of Tasks under an active Job, by using the Task APIs. Also note: when naming Jobs, avoid including sensitive information such as user names or secret project names. This information may appear in telemetry logs accessible to Microsoft Support engineers.
member.param: The Job to be added.

member.summary: Lists the execution status of the Job Preparation and Job Release Task for the specified Job across the Compute Nodes where the Job has run.
member.remarks: This API returns the Job Preparation and Job Release Task status on all Compute Nodes that have run the Job Preparation or Job Release Task. This includes Compute Nodes which have since been removed from the Pool. If this API is invoked on a Job which has no Job Preparation or Job Release Task, the Batch service returns HTTP status code 409 (Conflict) with an error code of JobPreparationTaskNotSpecified.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.JobOperationsExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods for JobOperations.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.JobOperationsExtensions.GetAllLifetimeStatistics(Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.IJobOperations,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.JobGetAllLifetimeStatisticsOptions)
member.summary: Gets lifetime summary statistics for all of the Jobs in the specified Account.
member.remarks: Statistics are aggregated across all Jobs that have ever existed in the Account, from Account creation to the last update time of the statistics. The statistics may not be immediately available. The Batch service performs periodic roll-up of statistics. The typical delay is about 30 minutes.
member.param: The operations group for this extension method.
Additional parameters for the operation

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.JobOperationsExtensions.GetAllLifetimeStatisticsAsync(Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.IJobOperations,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.JobGetAllLifetimeStatisticsOptions,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Gets lifetime summary statistics for all of the Jobs in the specified Account.
member.remarks: Statistics are aggregated across all Jobs that have ever existed in the Account, from Account creation to the last update time of the statistics. The statistics may not be immediately available. The Batch service performs periodic roll-up of statistics. The typical delay is about 30 minutes.
member.param: The operations group for this extension method.

The cancellation token.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.JobOperationsExtensions.Delete(Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.IJobOperations,System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.JobDeleteOptions)
member.summary: Deletes a Job.
member.remarks: Deleting a Job also deletes all Tasks that are part of that Job, and all Job statistics. This also overrides the retention period for Task data; that is, if the Job contains Tasks which are still retained on Compute Nodes, the Batch services deletes those Tasks' working directories and all their contents. When a Delete Job request is received, the Batch service sets the Job to the deleting state. All update operations on a Job that is in deleting state will fail with status code 409 (Conflict), with additional information indicating that the Job is being deleted.
member.param: The operations group for this extension method.
The ID of the Job to delete.
Additional parameters for the operation

member.summary: Lists the execution status of the Job Preparation and Job Release Task for the specified Job across the Compute Nodes where the Job has run.
member.remarks: This API returns the Job Preparation and Job Release Task status on all Compute Nodes that have run the Job Preparation or Job Release Task. This includes Compute Nodes which have since been removed from the Pool. If this API is invoked on a Job which has no Job Preparation or Job Release Task, the Batch service returns HTTP status code 409 (Conflict) with an error code of JobPreparationTaskNotSpecified.
member.param: The operations group for this extension method.
The NextLink from the previous successful call to List operation.
Additional parameters for the operation

The Job Schedule statistics are no longer accessible once the Job Schedule is deleted, though they are still counted towards Account lifetime statistics.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AffinityInformation.AffinityId
member.summary: Gets or sets an opaque string representing the location of a Compute Node or a Task that has run previously.
member.remarks: You can pass the affinityId of a Node to indicate that this Task needs to run on that Compute Node. Note that this is just a soft affinity. If the target Compute Node is busy or unavailable at the time the Task is scheduled, then the Task will be scheduled elsewhere.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AllocationState
member.summary: Defines values for AllocationState.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AllocationState.Steady
member.summary: The Pool is not resizing. There are no changes to the number of Compute Nodes in the Pool in progress. A Pool enters this state when it is created and when no operations are being performed on the Pool to change the number of Compute Nodes.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AllocationState.Resizing
member.summary: The Pool is resizing; that is, Compute Nodes are being added to or removed from the Pool.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AllocationState.Stopping
member.summary: The Pool was resizing, but the user has requested that the resize be stopped, but the stop request has not yet been completed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.ApplicationPackageReference.Version
member.summary: Gets or sets the version of the application to deploy. If omitted, the default version is deployed.
member.remarks: If this is omitted on a Pool, and no default version is specified for this application, the request fails with the error code InvalidApplicationPackageReferences and HTTP status code 409. If this is omitted on a Task, and no default version is specified for this application, the Task fails with a pre-processing error.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the AuthenticationTokenSettings class.
member.param: The Batch resources to which the token grants access.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AuthenticationTokenSettings.Access
member.summary: Gets or sets the Batch resources to which the token grants access.
member.remarks: The authentication token grants access to a limited set of Batch service operations. Currently the only supported value for the access property is 'job', which grants access to all operations related to the Job which contains the Task.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoPoolSpecification
member.summary: Specifies characteristics for a temporary 'auto pool'. The Batch service will create this auto Pool when the Job is submitted.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoPoolSpecification.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the AutoPoolSpecification class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoPoolSpecification.#ctor(Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.PoolLifetimeOption,System.String,System.Nullable{System.Boolean},Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.PoolSpecification)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the AutoPoolSpecification class.
member.param: The minimum lifetime of created auto Pools, and how multiple Jobs on a schedule are assigned to Pools.
A prefix to be added to the unique identifier when a Pool is automatically created.
Whether to keep an auto Pool alive after its lifetime expires.
The Pool specification for the auto Pool.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoPoolSpecification.AutoPoolIdPrefix
member.summary: Gets or sets a prefix to be added to the unique identifier when a Pool is automatically created.
member.remarks: The Batch service assigns each auto Pool a unique identifier on creation. To distinguish between Pools created for different purposes, you can specify this element to add a prefix to the ID that is assigned. The prefix can be up to 20 characters long.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoPoolSpecification.PoolLifetimeOption
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum lifetime of created auto Pools, and how multiple Jobs on a schedule are assigned to Pools.
member.remarks: Possible values include: 'jobSchedule', 'job'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoPoolSpecification.KeepAlive
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to keep an auto Pool alive after its lifetime expires.
member.remarks: If false, the Batch service deletes the Pool once its lifetime (as determined by the poolLifetimeOption setting) expires; that is, when the Job or Job Schedule completes. If true, the Batch service does not delete the Pool automatically. It is up to the user to delete auto Pools created with this option.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoPoolSpecification.Pool
member.summary: Gets or sets the Pool specification for the auto Pool.

member.summary: Specifies that the service should create a new user for the Task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoUserScope.Pool
member.summary: Specifies that the Task runs as the common auto user Account which is created on every Compute Node in a Pool.

member.summary: Specifies the parameters for the auto user that runs a Task on the Batch service.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the AutoUserSpecification class.

member.param: The scope for the auto user
The elevation level of the auto user.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoUserSpecification.Scope
member.summary: Gets or sets the scope for the auto user
member.remarks: The default value is pool. If the pool is running Windows a value of Task should be specified if stricter isolation between tasks is required. For example, if the task mutates the registry in a way which could impact other tasks, or if certificates have been specified on the pool which should not be accessible by normal tasks but should be accessible by StartTasks. Possible values include: 'task', 'pool'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.AutoUserSpecification.ElevationLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the elevation level of the auto user.
member.remarks: The default value is nonAdmin. Possible values include: 'nonAdmin', 'admin'

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Certificate class.
Initializes a new instance of the Certificate class.
member.param: The X.509 thumbprint of the Certificate. This is a sequence of up to 40 hex digits.
The algorithm used to derive the thumbprint.
The URL of the Certificate.
The current state of the Certificate.
The time at which the Certificate entered its current state.
The previous state of the Certificate.
The time at which the Certificate entered its previous state.
The public part of the Certificate as a base-64 encoded .cer file.
The error that occurred on the last attempt to delete this Certificate.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.Certificate.Thumbprint
member.summary: Gets or sets the X.509 thumbprint of the Certificate. This is a sequence of up to 40 hex digits.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.Certificate.ThumbprintAlgorithm
member.summary: Gets or sets the algorithm used to derive the thumbprint.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.Certificate.Url
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL of the Certificate.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.Certificate.State
member.summary: Gets or sets the current state of the Certificate.
member.remarks: Possible values include: 'active', 'deleting', 'deleteFailed'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.Certificate.StateTransitionTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the time at which the Certificate entered its current state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.Certificate.PreviousState
member.summary: Gets or sets the previous state of the Certificate.
member.remarks: This property is not set if the Certificate is in its initial active state. Possible values include: 'active', 'deleting', 'deleteFailed'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.Certificate.PreviousStateTransitionTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the time at which the Certificate entered its previous state.
member.remarks: This property is not set if the Certificate is in its initial Active state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.Certificate.PublicData
member.summary: Gets or sets the public part of the Certificate as a base-64 encoded .cer file.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.Certificate.DeleteCertificateError
member.summary: Gets or sets the error that occurred on the last attempt to delete this Certificate.
member.remarks: This property is set only if the Certificate is in the DeleteFailed state.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateAddParameter
member.summary: A Certificate that can be installed on Compute Nodes and can be used to authenticate operations on the machine.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateAddParameter.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CertificateAddParameter class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateAddParameter.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Nullable{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateFormat},System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CertificateAddParameter class.
member.param: The X.509 thumbprint of the Certificate. This is a sequence of up to 40 hex digits (it may include spaces but these are removed).
The algorithm used to derive the thumbprint. This must be sha1.
The base64-encoded contents of the Certificate. The maximum size is 10KB.
The format of the Certificate data.
The password to access the Certificate's private key.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateAddParameter.Thumbprint
member.summary: Gets or sets the X.509 thumbprint of the Certificate. This is a sequence of up to 40 hex digits (it may include spaces but these are removed).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateAddParameter.ThumbprintAlgorithm
member.summary: Gets or sets the algorithm used to derive the thumbprint. This must be sha1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateAddParameter.Data
member.summary: Gets or sets the base64-encoded contents of the Certificate. The maximum size is 10KB.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateAddParameter.CertificateFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the format of the Certificate data.
member.remarks: Possible values include: 'pfx', 'cer'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateAddParameter.Password
member.summary: Gets or sets the password to access the Certificate's private key.
member.remarks: This is required if the Certificate format is pfx. It should be omitted if the Certificate format is cer.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateReference
member.summary: A reference to a Certificate to be installed on Compute Nodes in a Pool.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateReference.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CertificateReference class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateReference.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Nullable{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateStoreLocation},System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateVisibility})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CertificateReference class.
member.param: The thumbprint of the Certificate.
The algorithm with which the thumbprint is associated. This must be sha1.
The location of the Certificate store on the Compute Node into which to install the Certificate.
The name of the Certificate store on the Compute Node into which to install the Certificate.
Which user Accounts on the Compute Node should have access to the private data of the Certificate.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateReference.Thumbprint
member.summary: Gets or sets the thumbprint of the Certificate.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateReference.ThumbprintAlgorithm
member.summary: Gets or sets the algorithm with which the thumbprint is associated. This must be sha1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateReference.StoreLocation
member.summary: Gets or sets the location of the Certificate store on the Compute Node into which to install the Certificate.
member.remarks: The default value is currentuser. This property is applicable only for Pools configured with Windows Compute Nodes (that is, created with cloudServiceConfiguration, or with virtualMachineConfiguration using a Windows Image reference). For Linux Compute Nodes, the Certificates are stored in a directory inside the Task working directory and an environment variable AZ_BATCH_CERTIFICATES_DIR is supplied to the Task to query for this location. For Certificates with visibility of 'remoteUser', a 'certs' directory is created in the user's home directory (e.g., /home/{user-name}/certs) and Certificates are placed in that directory. Possible values include: 'currentUser', 'localMachine'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateReference.StoreName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the Certificate store on the Compute Node into which to install the Certificate.
member.remarks: This property is applicable only for Pools configured with Windows Compute Nodes (that is, created with cloudServiceConfiguration, or with virtualMachineConfiguration using a Windows Image reference). Common store names include: My, Root, CA, Trust, Disallowed, TrustedPeople, TrustedPublisher, AuthRoot, AddressBook, but any custom store name can also be used. The default value is My.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateReference.Visibility
member.summary: Gets or sets which user Accounts on the Compute Node should have access to the private data of the Certificate.
member.remarks: You can specify more than one visibility in this collection. The default is all Accounts.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateState
member.summary: Defines values for CertificateState.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateState.Active
member.summary: The Certificate is available for use in Pools.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateState.Deleting
member.summary: The user has requested that the Certificate be deleted, but the delete operation has not yet completed. You may not reference the Certificate when creating or updating Pools.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateState.DeleteFailed
member.summary: The user requested that the Certificate be deleted, but there are Pools that still have references to the Certificate, or it is still installed on one or more Nodes. (The latter can occur if the Certificate has been removed from the Pool, but the Compute Node has not yet restarted. Compute Nodes refresh their Certificates only when they restart.) You may use the cancel Certificate delete operation to cancel the delete, or the delete Certificate operation to retry the delete.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateStoreLocation
member.summary: Defines values for CertificateStoreLocation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateStoreLocation.CurrentUser
member.summary: Certificates should be installed to the CurrentUser Certificate store.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateStoreLocation.LocalMachine
member.summary: Certificates should be installed to the LocalMachine Certificate store.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateVisibility
member.summary: Defines values for CertificateVisibility.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateVisibility.StartTask
member.summary: The Certificate should be visible to the user account under which the StartTask is run. Note that if AutoUser Scope is Pool for both the StartTask and a Task, this certificate will be visible to the Task as well.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateVisibility.Task
member.summary: The Certificate should be visible to the user accounts under which Job Tasks are run.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CertificateVisibility.RemoteUser
member.summary: The Certificate should be visible to the user accounts under which users remotely access the Compute Node.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.Id
member.summary: Gets or sets a string that uniquely identifies the Job within the Account.
member.remarks: The ID is case-preserving and case-insensitive (that is, you may not have two IDs within an Account that differ only by case).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.DisplayName
member.summary: Gets or sets the display name for the Job.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.UsesTaskDependencies
member.summary: Gets or sets whether Tasks in the Job can define dependencies on each other. The default is false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.Url
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL of the Job.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.ETag
member.summary: Gets or sets the ETag of the Job.
member.remarks: This is an opaque string. You can use it to detect whether the Job has changed between requests. In particular, you can be pass the ETag when updating a Job to specify that your changes should take effect only if nobody else has modified the Job in the meantime.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.LastModified
member.summary: Gets or sets the last modified time of the Job.
member.remarks: This is the last time at which the Job level data, such as the Job state or priority, changed. It does not factor in task-level changes such as adding new Tasks or Tasks changing state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.CreationTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the creation time of the Job.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.State
member.summary: Gets or sets the current state of the Job.
member.remarks: Possible values include: 'active', 'disabling', 'disabled', 'enabling', 'terminating', 'completed', 'deleting'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.StateTransitionTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the time at which the Job entered its current state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.PreviousState
member.summary: Gets or sets the previous state of the Job.
member.remarks: This property is not set if the Job is in its initial Active state. Possible values include: 'active', 'disabling', 'disabled', 'enabling', 'terminating', 'completed', 'deleting'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.PreviousStateTransitionTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the time at which the Job entered its previous state.
member.remarks: This property is not set if the Job is in its initial Active state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.Priority
member.summary: Gets or sets the priority of the Job.
member.remarks: Priority values can range from -1000 to 1000, with -1000 being the lowest priority and 1000 being the highest priority. The default value is 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.Constraints
member.summary: Gets or sets the execution constraints for the Job.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.JobManagerTask
member.summary: Gets or sets details of a Job Manager Task to be launched when the Job is started.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.JobPreparationTask
member.summary: Gets or sets the Job Preparation Task.
member.remarks: The Job Preparation Task is a special Task run on each Compute Node before any other Task of the Job.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.JobReleaseTask
member.summary: Gets or sets the Job Release Task.
member.remarks: The Job Release Task is a special Task run at the end of the Job on each Compute Node that has run any other Task of the Job.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.CommonEnvironmentSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets the list of common environment variable settings. These environment variables are set for all Tasks in the Job (including the Job Manager, Job Preparation and Job Release Tasks).
member.remarks: Individual Tasks can override an environment setting specified here by specifying the same setting name with a different value.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.PoolInfo
member.summary: Gets or sets the Pool settings associated with the Job.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.OnAllTasksComplete
member.summary: Gets or sets the action the Batch service should take when all Tasks in the Job are in the completed state.
member.remarks: The default is noaction. Possible values include: 'noAction', 'terminateJob'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.OnTaskFailure
member.summary: Gets or sets the action the Batch service should take when any Task in the Job fails.
member.remarks: A Task is considered to have failed if has a failureInfo. A failureInfo is set if the Task completes with a non-zero exit code after exhausting its retry count, or if there was an error starting the Task, for example due to a resource file download error. The default is noaction. Possible values include: 'noAction', 'performExitOptionsJobAction'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.NetworkConfiguration
member.summary: Gets or sets the network configuration for the Job.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.Metadata
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of name-value pairs associated with the Job as metadata.
member.remarks: The Batch service does not assign any meaning to metadata; it is solely for the use of user code.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.ExecutionInfo
member.summary: Gets or sets the execution information for the Job.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Protocol.Models.CloudJob.Stats
member.summary: Gets or sets resource usage statistics for the entire lifetime of the Job.
member.remarks: This property is populated only if the CloudJob was retrieved with an expand clause including the 'stats' attribute; otherwise it is null. The statistics may not be immediately available. The Batch service performs periodic roll-up of statistics. The typical delay is about 30 minutes.
