member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation
member.summary: Details about the execution of a Job Preparation task on a compute node.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.ContainerInformation
member.summary: Gets information about the container under which the task is executing.
member.remarks: This property is set only if the task runs in a container context.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.EndTime
member.summary: Gets the time at which the task completed.
member.remarks: This property is only returned if the task is in the state.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.ExitCode
member.summary: Gets the exit code of the program specified on the task command line.
member.remarks: This property is only returned if the task is in the state. The exit code for a process reflects the specific convention implemented by the application developer for that process. If you use the exit code value to make decisions in your code, be sure that you know the exit code convention used by the application process. Note that the exit code may also be generated by the compute node operating system, such as when a process is forcibly terminated.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.FailureInformation
member.summary: Gets information describing the task failure, if any.
member.remarks: This property is set only if the task is in the state and encountered a failure.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.LastRetryTime
member.summary: Gets the most recent time at which this task's execution was retried by the Batch service.
member.remarks: This is only returned if the is not 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.Result
member.summary: Gets the result of the task execution.
member.remarks: If the value is , then the details of the failure can be found in the property.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.RetryCount
member.summary: Gets the number of times the task has been retried by the Batch service. Every time the task exits with a non-zero exit code, it is deemed a task failure. The Batch service will retry the task up to the limit specified by the .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.StartTime
member.summary: Gets the time at which the task started running. Note that every time the task is restarted, this value is updated.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.State
member.summary: Gets the current state of the task.
member.remarks: Running means the task is currently running. Completed means the task has completed. The Completed state includes the case where the task exits successfully with exit code 0 and the cases where the system fails to start the task process due to scheduling errors or the retry limit has reached after numerous task failures.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.TaskRootDirectory
member.summary: Gets the root directory of the Job Preparation task on the compute node. You can use this path to retrieve files created by the task, such as log files.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.TaskRootDirectoryUrl
member.summary: Gets the URL to the root directory of the Job Preparation task on the compute node.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask
member.summary: A Job Release task to run on job completion on any compute node where the job has run.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The command line of the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask.CommandLine
member.summary: Gets or sets the command line of the task.
member.remarks: The command line does not run under a shell, and therefore cannot take advantage of shell features such as environment variable expansion. If you want to take advantage of such features, you should invoke the shell in the command line, for example using "cmd /c MyCommand" in Windows or "/bin/sh -c MyCommand" in Linux. If the command line refers to file paths, it should use a relative path (relative to the task working directory), or use the Batch provided environment variables (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/batch/batch-compute-node-environment-variables).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask.ContainerSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets the settings for the container under which the task runs.
member.remarks: When this is specified, all directories recursively below the AZ_BATCH_NODE_ROOT_DIR (the root of Azure Batch directories on the node) are mapped into the container, all task environment variables are mapped into the container, and the task command line is executed in the container. Files produced in the container outside of AZ_BATCH_NODE_ROOT_DIR might not be reflected to the host disk, meaning that Batch file APIs will not be able to access them.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask.EnvironmentSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets the collection of EnvironmentSetting instances.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask.Id
member.summary: Gets or sets the id of the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask.MaxWallClockTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum duration of time for which a task is allowed to run from the time it is created.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask.ResourceFiles
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of files that the Batch service will download to the compute node before running the command line.
member.remarks: There is a maximum size for the list of resource files. When the max size is exceeded, the request will fail and the response error code will be RequestEntityTooLarge. If this occurs, the collection of resource files must be reduced in size. This can be achieved using .zip files, Application Packages, or Docker Containers.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask.RetentionTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration of time for which files in the task's working directory are retained, from the time it completes execution. After this duration, the task's working directory is reclaimed.
member.remarks: The default is 7 days, i.e. the task directory will be retained for 7 days unless the compute node is removed or the job is deleted.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobReleaseTask.UserIdentity
member.summary: Gets or sets the user identity under which the task runs.
member.remarks: If omitted, the task runs as a non-administrative user unique to the task.

member.summary: Gets the time at which the next job will be scheduled under this job schedule. This property is only returned for active job schedules.

member.summary: Resource usage statistics for a .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.FailedTaskCount
member.summary: Gets the total number of tasks in the job that failed during the given time range.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.KernelCpuTime
member.summary: Gets the total kernel mode CPU time (per core) consumed by all tasks in the job schedule.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.LastUpdateTime
member.summary: Gets the time at which the statistics were last updated. All statistics are limited to the range between and this value.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.ReadIOGiB
member.summary: Gets the total gibibytes of I/O read from disk by all tasks in the job schedule.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.ReadIOps
member.summary: Gets the total number of disk read operations made by all tasks in the job schedule.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.StartTime
member.summary: Gets the start time of the time range covered by the statistics.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.SucceededTaskCount
member.summary: Gets the total number of tasks successfully completed in the job schedule.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.TaskRetryCount
member.summary: Gets the total number of retries that occurred on all tasks in the job schedule.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.Url
member.summary: Gets the URL of the statistics.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.UserCpuTime
member.summary: Gets the total user mode CPU time (per core) consumed by all tasks in the job schedule.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.WaitTime
member.summary: Gets the total wait time of all tasks in jobs created under the schedule. The wait time for a task is defined as the elapsed time between the creation of the task and the start of task execution. (If the task is retried due to failures, the wait time is the time to the most recent task execution.)
member.remarks: This value is only reported in the account lifetime statistics.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.WallClockTime
member.summary: Gets the total wall clock time of all tasks in the job schedule. Note that if any task was retried multiple times, this includes the wall clock time of all the task retries.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.WriteIOGiB
member.summary: Gets the total gibibytes of I/O written to disk by all tasks in the job schedule.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.JobScheduleStatistics.WriteIOps
member.summary: Gets the total number of disk write operations made by all tasks in the job schedule.

The group ID of the user account.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.LinuxUserConfiguration.Gid
member.summary: Gets or sets the group ID of the user account.
member.remarks: The and properties must be specified together or not at all. If not specified, the underlying operating system picks the gid.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.LinuxUserConfiguration.SshPrivateKey
member.summary: Gets or sets the SSH private key for the user account.
member.remarks: The private key must not be password protected. The private key is used to automatically configure asymmetric-key based authentication for SSH between nodes in a Linux pool when the pool's property is true (it is ignored if is false). It does this by placing the key pair into the user's .ssh directory. If not specified, password-less SSH is not configured between nodes (no modification of the user's .ssh directory is done)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.LinuxUserConfiguration.Uid
member.summary: Gets or sets the user ID of the user account.
member.remarks: The and properties must be specified together or not at all. If not specified, the underlying operating system picks the uid.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.MultiInstanceSettings
member.summary: Settings which specify how to run a multi-instance task. Multi-instance tasks are commonly used to support MPI tasks. In the MPI case, if any of the subtasks fail (for example due to exiting with a non-zero exit code) the entire multi-instance task fails. The multi-instance task is then terminated and retried, up to its retry limit. For more information see https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/batch-mpi/.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.MultiInstanceSettings.#ctor(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The command to run on the compute node instances for coordinating among the subtasks.
The number of compute nodes required by the multi-instance task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.MultiInstanceSettings.CommonResourceFiles
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of files that the Batch service will download before running the coordination command line.
member.remarks: The difference between common resource files and task resource files is that common resource files are downloaded for all subtasks including the primary, whereas task resource files are downloaded only for the primary. There is a maximum size for the list of resource files. When the max size is exceeded, the request will fail and the response error code will be RequestEntityTooLarge. If this occurs, the collection of resource files must be reduced in size. This can be achieved using .zip files, Application Packages, or Docker Containers.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.MultiInstanceSettings.CoordinationCommandLine
member.summary: Gets or sets the command to run on the compute node instances for coordinating among the subtasks.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.MultiInstanceSettings.NumberOfInstances
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of compute nodes required by the multi-instance task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkConfiguration.DynamicVNetAssignmentScope
member.summary: Gets or sets the scope of the dynamic VNet assignment.
member.remarks: This property can only be specified for pools created with a .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkConfiguration.EndpointConfiguration
member.summary: Gets or sets the configuration for endpoints on compute nodes in the Batch pool.
member.remarks: This property can only be specified for pools created with a .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkConfiguration.PublicIPs
member.summary: Gets or sets the list of public IPs which the Batch service will use when provisioning Compute Nodes.
member.remarks: The number of IPs specified here limits the maximum size of the Pool - 50 dedicated nodes or 20 low-priority nodes can be allocated for each public IP. For example, a pool needing 150 dedicated VMs would need at least 3 public IPs specified. Each element of this collection is of the form: /subscriptions/{subscription}/resourceGroups/{group}/providers/Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses/{ip}.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkConfiguration.SubnetId
member.summary: Gets or sets the ARM resource identifier of the virtual network subnet which the compute nodes of the pool will join.
member.remarks: The virtual network must be in the same region and subscription as the Azure Batch account. The specified subnet should have enough free IP addresses to accommodate the number of nodes in the pool. If the subnet doesn't have enough free IP addresses, the pool will partially allocate compute nodes, and a resize error will occur. The 'MicrosoftAzureBatch' service principal must have the 'Classic Virtual Machine Contributor' Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) role for the specified VNet. The specified subnet must allow communication from the Azure Batch service to be able to schedule tasks on the compute nodes. This can be verified by checking if the specified VNet has any associated Network Security Groups (NSG). If communication to the compute nodes in the specified subnet is denied by an NSG, then the Batch service will set the state of the compute nodes to unusable. For pools created via only only ARM virtual networks ('Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks') are supported, but for pools created with both ARM and classic virtual networks are supported. If the specified VNet has any associated Network Security Groups (NSG), then a few reserved system ports must be enabled for inbound communication. For pools created with a , enable ports 29876 and 29877, as well as port 22 for Linux and port 3389 for Windows. For pools created with a , enable ports 10100, 20100, and 30100. Also enable outbound connections to Azure Storage on port 443. For more details see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/batch/batch-api-basics#virtual-network-vnet-and-firewall-configuration.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkSecurityGroupRule
member.summary: A network security group rule to apply to an inbound endpoint.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkSecurityGroupRule.#ctor(System.Int32,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.NetworkSecurityGroupRuleAccess,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{System.String})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The priority for this rule.
The action that should be taken for a specified IP address, subnet range or tag.
The source address prefix or tag to match for the rule.
The source port ranges to match for the rule.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkSecurityGroupRule.Access
member.summary: Gets the action that should be taken for a specified IP address, subnet range or tag.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkSecurityGroupRule.Priority
member.summary: Gets the priority for this rule.
member.remarks: Priorities within a pool must be unique and are evaluated in order of priority. The lower the number the higher the priority. For example, rules could be specified with order numbers of 150, 250, and 350. The rule with the order number of 150 takes precedence over the rule that has an order of 250. Allowed priorities are 150 to 3500.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkSecurityGroupRule.SourceAddressPrefix
member.summary: Gets the source address prefix or tag to match for the rule.
member.remarks: Valid values are a single IP address (i.e. 10.10.10.10), IP subnet (i.e. 192.168.1.0/24), default tag, or * (for all addresses).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.NetworkSecurityGroupRule.SourcePortRanges
member.summary: Gets the source port ranges to match for the rule.
member.remarks: Valid values are '*' (for all ports 0 - 65535), a specific port (i.e. 22), or a port range (i.e. 100-200). The ports must be in the range of 0 to 65535. Each entry in this collection must not overlap any other entry (either a range or an individual port). If any other values are provided the request fails with HTTP status code 400. The default value is '*'

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.OutputFile
member.summary: A specification for uploading files from an Azure Batch node to another location after the Batch service has finished executing the task process.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.OutputFile.#ctor(System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.OutputFileDestination,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.OutputFileUploadOptions)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A pattern indicating which file(s) to upload.
The destination for the output file(s).
Additional options for the upload operation, including under what conditions to perform the upload.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.OutputFile.Destination
member.summary: Gets the destination for the output file(s).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.OutputFile.FilePattern
member.summary: Gets a pattern indicating which file(s) to upload.

remarks.para: Both relative and absolute paths are supported. Relative paths are relative to the Task working directory.

The following wildcards are supported: * matches 0 or more characters (for example pattern abc* would match abc or abcdef), ** matches any directory, ? matches any single character, [abc] matches one character in the brackets, and [a-c] matches one character in the range.
Brackets can include a negation to match any character not specified (for example [!abc] matches any character but a, b, or c).

If a file name starts with "." it is ignored by default but may be matched by specifying it explicitly (for example *.gif will not match .a.gif, but .*.gif will). A simple example: **\*.txt matches any file that does not start in '.' and ends with .txt in the Task working directory or any subdirectory.
If the filename contains a wildcard character it can be escaped using brackets (for example abc[*] would match a file named abc*).
Note that both \ and / are treated as directory separators on Windows, but only / is on Linux.
Environment variables (%var% on Windows or $var on Linux) are expanded prior to the pattern being applied.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.OutputFile.UploadOptions
member.summary: Gets additional options for the upload operation, including under what conditions to perform the upload.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.OutputFileBlobContainerDestination.Path
member.summary: Gets the destination blob or virtual directory within the Azure Storage container to which to upload the file(s).

remarks.para: If refers to a specific file (i.e. it contains no wildcards), then this is the name of the blob to which to upload that file.
If contains wildcards (and may therefore match multiple files), then this then this is the name of the blob virtual directory (which is prepended to each blob name) to which to upload the file(s).
If omitted, file(s) are uploaded to the root of the container with a blob name matching their file name.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether the pool size should automatically adjust over time.

remarks.para: If false, one of the or property is required.
If true, the property is required. The pool automatically resizes according to the formula.
The default value is false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.PoolSpecification.AutoScaleEvaluationInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets a time interval at which to automatically adjust the pool size according to the .
member.remarks: The default value is 15 minutes. The minimum allowed value is 5 minutes.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.PoolSpecification.AutoScaleFormula
member.summary: Gets or sets a formula for the desired number of compute nodes in the pool.

remarks.para: For how to write autoscale formulas, see https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/batch-automatic-scaling/. This property is required if is set to true. It must be null if AutoScaleEnabled is false.
The formula is checked for validity before the pool is created. If the formula is not valid, an exception is thrown when you try to commit the .

member.summary: A file to be downloaded to a compute node from Azure Blob Storage, such as task executables and task input data files.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ResourceFile.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The URL of the file to download.
The file permission mode attribute in octal format.
The location on the compute node to which to download the file(s), relative to the task's working directory.
The URL of the blob container within Azure Blob Storage.
The storage container name in the auto storage account.
The blob prefix to use when downloading blobs from an Azure Storage container. Only the blobs whose names begin with the specified prefix will be downloaded.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ResourceFile.AutoStorageContainerName
member.summary: Gets the storage container name in the auto storage account.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ResourceFile.BlobPrefix
member.summary: Gets the blob prefix to use when downloading blobs from an Azure Storage container. Only the blobs whose names begin with the specified prefix will be downloaded.
member.remarks: This property is valid only when or is used. This prefix can be a partial filename or a subdirectory. If a prefix is not specified, all the files in the container will be downloaded.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ResourceFile.FileMode
member.summary: Gets the file permission mode attribute in octal format.

remarks.para: This property is applicable only if the resource file is downloaded to a Linux node. This property will be ignored if it is specified for a which will be downloaded to a Windows node. If this property is not specified for a Linux node, then the default value is 0770.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ResourceFile.FilePath
member.summary: Gets the location on the compute node to which to download the file(s), relative to the task's working directory.
member.remarks: If the property is specified, this is required and describes the path which the file will be downloaded to, including the filename. Otherwise, if the or property is specified, this is optional and is the directory to download the files to. In the case where this is used as a directory, any directory structure already associated with the input data will be retained in full and appended to the specified directory. The specified relative path cannot break out of the task's working directory (for example by using '..').

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ResourceFile.HttpUrl
member.summary: Gets the URL of the file to download.
member.remarks: If the URL is Azure Blob Storage, it must be readable using anonymous access; that is, the Batch service does not present any credentials when downloading the blob. There are two ways to get such a URL for a blob in Azure storage: include a Shared Access Signature (SAS) granting read permissions on the blob, or set the ACL for the blob or its container to allow public access.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ResourceFile.StorageContainerUrl
member.summary: Gets the URL of the blob container within Azure Blob Storage.
member.remarks: This URL must be readable and listable using anonymous access; that is, the Batch service does not present any credentials when downloading blobs from the container. There are two ways to get such a URL for a container in Azure storage: include a Shared Access Signature (SAS) granting read permissions on the container, or set the ACL for the container to allow public access.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.StartTask
member.summary: A task which is run when a compute node joins a pool in the Azure Batch service, or when the compute node is rebooted or reimaged.

remarks.para: Batch will retry tasks when a recovery operation is triggered on a compute node. Examples of recovery operations include (but are not limited to) when an unhealthy compute node is rebooted or a compute node disappeared due to host failure. Retries due to recovery operations are independent of and are not counted against the . Even if the is 0, an internal retry due to a recovery operation may occur. Because of this, all tasks should be idempotent. This means tasks need to tolerate being interrupted and restarted without causing any corruption or duplicate data.

The best practice for long running tasks is to use some form of checkpointing. Special care should be taken to avoid start tasks which create breakaway process or install/launch services from the start task working directory, as this will block Batch from being able to re-run the start task.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.StartTask.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The command line of the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.StartTask.CommandLine
member.summary: Gets or sets the command line of the task.
member.remarks: The command line does not run under a shell, and therefore cannot take advantage of shell features such as environment variable expansion. If you want to take advantage of such features, you should invoke the shell in the command line, for example using "cmd /c MyCommand" in Windows or "/bin/sh -c MyCommand" in Linux. If the command line refers to file paths, it should use a relative path (relative to the task working directory), or use the Batch provided environment variables (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/batch/batch-compute-node-environment-variables).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.StartTask.ContainerSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets the settings for the container under which the task runs.
member.remarks: When this is specified, all directories recursively below the AZ_BATCH_NODE_ROOT_DIR (the root of Azure Batch directories on the node) are mapped into the container, all task environment variables are mapped into the container, and the task command line is executed in the container. Files produced in the container outside of AZ_BATCH_NODE_ROOT_DIR might not be reflected to the host disk, meaning that Batch file APIs will not be able to access them.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.StartTask.EnvironmentSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets a set of environment settings for the start task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.StartTask.MaxTaskRetryCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of retries for the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.StartTask.ResourceFiles
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of files that the Batch service will download to the compute node before running the command line.
member.remarks: There is a maximum size for the list of resource files. When the max size is exceeded, the request will fail and the response error code will be RequestEntityTooLarge. If this occurs, the collection of resource files must be reduced in size. This can be achieved using .zip files, Application Packages, or Docker Containers.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.StartTask.UserIdentity
member.summary: Gets or sets the user identity under which the task runs.
member.remarks: If omitted, the task runs as a non-administrative user unique to the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.StartTask.WaitForSuccess
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Batch service should wait for the start task to complete before scheduling any tasks on the compute node.
member.remarks: If this is not specified, the default is true.

member.summary: Return a protocol object of the requested type.
member.returns: The protocol object of the requested type.

member.remarks: This property is only returned if the task is in the state. The exit code for a process reflects the specific convention implemented by the application developer for that process. If you use the exit code value to make decisions in your code, be sure that you know the exit code convention used by the application process. Note that the exit code may also be generated by the compute node operating system, such as when a process is forcibly terminated.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.TaskConstraints
member.summary: Defines the constraints on a particular Azure Batch task.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.TaskConstraints.#ctor(System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The maximum elapsed time that the task may run, measured from the time the task starts.

The minimum time to retain the working directory for the task on the compute node where it ran, from the time it completes execution. After this time, the Batch service may delete the working directory and all its contents.
The maximum number of retries for the task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.TaskConstraints.MaxTaskRetryCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of retries for the task.
member.remarks: Note that this value specifically controls the number of retries for the task executable due to a nonzero exit code. The Batch service will try the task once, and may then retry up to this limit. For example, if the maximum retry count is 3, Batch tries the task up to 4 times (one initial try and 3 retries). If the maximum retry count is 0, the Batch service does not retry the task after the first attempt. If the maximum retry count is -1, the Batch service retries the task without limit. Resource files and application packages are only downloaded again if the task is retried on a new compute node.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.TaskConstraints.MaxWallClockTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum elapsed time that the task may run, measured from the time the task starts.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.TaskConstraints.RetentionTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum time to retain the working directory for the task on the compute node where it ran, from the time it completes execution. After this time, the Batch service may delete the working directory and all its contents.
member.remarks: The default is 7 days, i.e. the task directory will be retained for 7 days unless the compute node is removed or the job is deleted.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IFileStagingArtifact
member.summary: Contains information about a file staging process. File staging is typically performed for a (see ).

remarks.para: IFileStagingArtifact allows an application to customize and to obtain information about the process of uploading files to the cloud, for example as part of a task-related operation such as JobOperations.AddTaskAsync or CloudJob.AddTaskAsync. Applications may use this information to, for example, find out about containers that were created in Azure Storage as part of the upload process.

When JobOperations.AddTaskAsync is called, the Batch client sends the tasks to the Batch service in collections. As each collection is processed, the Batch client performs file staging for that collection: it examines the tasks to see if any of them specify any , and if so creates a dictionary entry for each type of in the FilesToStage collection. The key of the dictionary entry is the of the IFileStagingProvider and the value is an instance of the corresponding implementation of IFileStagingArtifact. For example, if FilesToStage includes one or more FileToStage objects (from the Microsoft.Azure.Batch.FileStaging library), then the dictionary contains an entry whose key is typeof(FileToStage) and whose value is an instance of SequentialFileStagingArtifact.

When the Add Task operation completes, or during the Add Task operation if the application is multi-threaded, you can examine the dictionary and convert each IFileStagingArtifact to the appropriate type to retrieve the type-specific information. For example, if your Add Task operation specified one or more FileToStage objects, you can locate the dictionary entry keyed by typeof(FileToStage), cast the value to SequentialFileStagingArtifact, and examine the SequentialFileStagingArtifact.BlobContainerCreated property to determine if the upload process created a blob container in Azure Storage and if so the name of that container. This example could be useful for cleaning up automatically created containers.

(Single-task Add Task operations work similarly, except that in a multi-task Add Task operation, there is a dictionary for each collection of tasks, and the dictionaries are collected in a , whereas in a single-task Add Task operation there is only a single dictionary.)

In a single-task Add Task operation, you can also use the dictionary to customize the file staging process, by pre-populating it with appropriate entries. For example, suppose you wish to control the for a group of FileToStage objects. Then you could initialize the dictionary with { typeof(FileToStage), new SequentialFileStagingArtifact { NamingFragment = "myname" } } before passing it to AddTaskAsync. The FileToStage implementation of IFileStagingProvider would then use your SequentialFileStagingArtifact instead of creating its own. (This feature is not available in multi-task Add Task operations.)

You may also encounter IFileStagingArtifact if you are developing a custom . In this case you will typically create a custom implementation of IFileStagingArtifact to report implementation-specific information about your file staging process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IFileStagingArtifact.NamingFragment
member.summary: Gets or sets a name fragment that can be used when constructing default names.
member.remarks: Although a caller may set this property, the implementation is not required to respect it.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IInheritedBehaviors
member.summary: Methods and properties that are inherited from the instantiating parent object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IInheritedBehaviors.CustomBehaviors
member.summary: This collection is initially populated by instantiation or by copying from the instantiating parent object (inheritance). In this model, the collections are independent but the members are shared references. Members of this collection alter or customize various behaviors of Azure Batch Service client objects. These behaviors are generally inherited by any child class instances. Modifications are applied in the order of the collection. The last write wins.

An interface to manage objects that can be modified.
Please use "Explicit Interface Implementation" to hide these methods on public classes.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IModifiable.HasBeenModified
member.summary:
Returns true if the object has been modified. This is recursive through complex child properties.
Note special care must be take for "administrative" property writes as they might trigger a false positive on this test.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IPagedEnumerable`1
member.summary:
Exposes enumerators for a paged collection. These enumerators support simple iteration over a paged collection of a specified type.
Paged collections are backed by one or more calls to the Batch Service. Each of these calls can return a variable sized page of data which is then consumed by the enumerator.
member.typeparam: The type of objects to enumerate.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IPagedEnumerable`1.GetPagedEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an asynchronous enumerator that iterates through the paged collection.
member.returns: The type of objects to enumerate.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IPagedEnumerator`1
member.summary:
An enumerator which exposes an asynchronous mechanism for iteration.
Enumerator instances are not threadsafe.
Each enumerator fetches the collection from the server. As a consequence, each enumerator can see different data (collection size, contents, etc.).
Care should be taken to avoid multiple retrievals of the data from the server via casual use of foreach/ForeachAsync and other collection operations.
member.typeparam: The type of the enumerator.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IPagedEnumerator`1.Current
member.summary: Gets the element in the collection at the current position of the enumerator.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IPagedEnumerator`1.MoveNextAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous call to advance the enumerator to the next element of the collection.
member.param: A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: A object that represents the asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IPagedEnumerator`1.ResetAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous call to set the enumerator to its initial position, which is before the first element in the collection.
member.param: A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: A object that represents the asynchronous operation.

member.summary: Adds tasks to a job.
member.param: The id of the job to which to add the tasks.
The s to add.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .

Controls the number of simultaneous parallel AddTaskCollection requests issued to the Batch service. Each AddTaskCollection request contains at most tasks in it. Also controls the cancellation token for the operation. If omitted, the default is used (see .)

An optional collection to receive information about the file staging process (see ). An entry is added to the for each set of tasks grouped for submission to the Batch service. Unlike single-task adds, you cannot use this parameter to customize the file staging process. For more information about the format of each entry, see .
The amount of time after which the operation times out.
member.returns: A object that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: The add task operation runs asynchronously.

This method is not atomic; that is, it is possible for the method to start adding tasks and then fail. The collection of tasks to add is broken down into chunks of size at most , and an AddTaskCollection request is issued for each chunk. Requests may be issued in parallel according to the .

Issuing a large number of simultaneous requests to the Batch service can incur HTTP connection restrictions. If you are performing many of these operations in parallel (or have specified a large MaxDegreeOfParallelism in the parallelOptions) and are seeing client side timeouts, please see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.servicepointmanager.defaultconnectionlimit%28v=vs.110%29.aspx .

The progress of the operation in the face of errors is determined by behavior. You do not normally need to specify this behavior, as the Batch client uses a default which works in normal circumstances. If you do want to customize this behavior, specify an AddTaskCollectionResultHandler in the or collections.

member.exception: Thrown if one or more requests to the Batch service fail.

member.summary: Gets lifetime summary statistics for all of the jobs in the current account. Statistics are aggregated across all jobs that have ever existed in the account, from account creation to the last update time of the statistics. The statistics may not be immediately available. The Batch service performs periodic roll-up of statistics. The typical delay is about 30 minutes.
member.param: A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ODATADetailLevel
member.summary: Controls the amount of detail requested from the Azure Batch service when listing or retrieving resources, using OData query clauses.

remarks.para: Azure Batch supports OData queries, which allow the client to gain finer control over query performance by controlling which resources are returned in List operations (), and which properties of each resource are returned in List, Get or Refresh operations ( and ).

By default, if you do not pass a to a List, Get or Refresh operation, the Batch client specifies no filter (all records are returned), no select clause (all simple properties are returned) and no expand clause (associated entities are not returned). Consequently, by default, associated entity properties are null, rather than being populated like other properties. Refer to individual class documentation to find out which properties are considered associated entities and need to be expanded to be populated.

Because the OData queries are passed directly to the REST API, clause strings must use the JSON attribute names from the REST API, which are not always the same as .NET property names. For example, the .NET CloudPool.VirtualMachineSize property corresponds to the vmSize attribute in the REST API; therefore, to filter a pool list operations by VM size, you would need to write vmSize rather than VirtualMachineSize in your filter string. Refer to the REST API documentation to find out the JSON attribute name corresponding to a .NET property.
For additional information about using OData to efficiently query the Azure Batch service, see Efficient List Queries on MSDN.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ODATADetailLevel.FilterClause
member.summary: Gets or sets the OData filter clause. Used to restrict a list operation to items that match specified criteria.

remarks.para: This is an optional OData $filter expression string (see the OData specification). For example, you can restrict a operation to return only active pools with the expression state eq 'active'.
Filters must be specified using REST API attribute names, not .NET property names.
The default is no filter expression, which means all resources are returned.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ODATADetailLevel.SelectClause
member.summary: Gets or sets the OData select clause. Used to retrieve only specific properties instead of all object properties.

remarks.para: This is an optional OData $select expression string (see the OData specification). If you provide a SelectClause, then only the properties listed in that clause are populated; other properties have their default values (typically null). For example, if you perform a operation with a SelectClause of id,displayName, then each will have its and properties populated, but other properties such as will not be retrieved and therefore will have their default values (typically null).

If, when an entity was retrieved (via a List, Get or Refresh), you specifed a SelectClause which did not include the property or properties that uniquely identify the object (usually the Id property, but for the Thumbprint and ThumbprintAlgorithm properties, then any methods that access the Batch service to retrieve data or perform operations will fail. This includes most methods on the object, including and . You can still access properties (though only properties included in the SelectClause will be populated).
Selections must be specified using REST API attribute names, not .NET property names.
The default is no select expression, which means all properties are returned.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ODATADetailLevel.ExpandClause
member.summary: Gets or sets the OData expand clause. Used to retrieve associated entities of the main entity being retrieved.

remarks.para: This is an optional OData $expand expression string (see the OData specification). Properties containing associated entities will be null unless included in an ExpandClause. Specifically, if you perform a List, Get or Refresh and do not specify an ExpandClause, then all associated entity properties will be null. For example, if you perform a operation without an ExpandClause then the property will be null. To populate the Statistics property you must supply an ExpandClause of stats. Refer to individual class documentation to find out which properties are considered associated entities.

If you specify both an ExpandClause and a , then properties listed in the ExpandClause must be repeated in the SelectClause (because only properties listed in the SelectClause are included in the service response). (This requirement does not arise if you do not specify a SelectClause, because that means 'include all properties in the response.')
Expansions must be specified using REST API attribute names, not .NET property names.
The default is no expand expression, which means no associated objects are returned (and the corresponding properties are null).

member.summary: Resizes the specified pool.
member.param: The id of the pool.
The desired number of dedicated compute nodes in the pool. At least one of and is required.
The desired number of low-priority compute nodes in the pool. At least one of and is required.

The timeout for allocation of compute nodes to the pool or removal of compute nodes from the pool. If the pool has not reached the target size after this time, the resize is stopped. The default is 15 minutes.
Specifies how to handle tasks already running, and when the nodes running them may be removed from the pool, if the pool size is decreasing. The default is .
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: A that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: The resize operation requests that the pool be resized. The request puts the pool in the allocation state. The Batch service will perform the actual resize without any further client action, and set the allocation state to once complete.

You can only resize a pool when its is . You cannot resize pools which are configured for automatic scaling (that is, the property of the pool is true). If you decrease the pool size, the Batch service chooses which nodes to remove. To remove specific nodes, call .
The resize operation runs asynchronously.

If the file-path parameter represents a directory instead of a file, you can set the optional recursive parameter to true to delete the directory and all of the files and subdirectories in it. If recursive is false then the directory must be empty or deletion will fail.

member.summary: Gets lifetime summary statistics for all of the pools in the current account. Statistics are aggregated across all pools that have ever existed in the account, from account creation to the last update time of the statistics. The statistics may not be immediately available. The Batch service performs periodic roll-up of statistics. The typical delay is about 30 minutes.
member.param: A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: The aggregated pool statistics.
member.remarks: The get statistics operation runs asynchronously.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.PoolOperations.UploadComputeNodeBatchServiceLogsAsync(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.DateTime,System.Nullable{System.DateTime},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Upload Azure Batch service log files from the specified compute node.
member.param: The id of the pool that contains the compute node.
The id of the compute node.
The URL of the container within Azure Blob Storage to which to upload the Batch Service log file(s). The URL must include a Shared Access Signature (SAS) granting write permissions to the container.

The start of the time range from which to upload Batch Service log file(s). Any log file containing a log message in the time range will be uploaded. This means that the operation might retrieve more logs than have been requested since the entire log file is always uploaded.

The end of the time range from which to upload Batch Service log file(s). Any log file containing a log message in the time range will be uploaded. This means that the operation might retrieve more logs than have been requested since the entire log file is always uploaded. If this is omitted, the default is the current time.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: A that represents the asynchronous operation.
member.remarks: This is for gathering Azure Batch service log files in an automated fashion from nodes if you are experiencing an error and wish to escalate to Azure support. The Azure Batch service log files should be shared with Azure support to aid in debugging issues with the Batch service.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Batch.TaskStateMonitor.WhenAll(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask},Microsoft.Azure.Batch.Common.TaskState,System.TimeSpan,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.ODATAMonitorControl,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior})
member.summary: Monitors a collection until each of its members has reached a desired state at least once.

remarks.para: The state of each instance is assumed to be authoritative at the time of the call. Instances that are already at the are ignored. The instances in the collection are treated as read-only. This means that when the call completes (timeout or not) the instances should be refreshed before using.
This method runs asynchronously.

member.param: The collection of tasks to monitor.
The target state of the tasks. The method will exit when all tasks have reached this state at least once.
The maximum amount of time this call will wait before timing out.
Controls various settings of the monitor, such as delay between each poll.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
member.returns: A that represents the asynchronous operation.
member.exception: Thrown if the has elapsed.
